articles.headline: For Obama, Executive Order on Immigration Would Be a Turnabout
articles.snippet: President Obama is poised to ignore his longtime opposition to a decision that would shield immigrants from deportation without an act of Congress.
articles.abstract: President Obama is poised to ignore his longtime opposition to a decision that would shield immigrants from deportation without an act of Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is poised to ignore stark warnings that executive action on immigration would amount to “violating our laws” and would be “very difficult to defend legally.”

articles.headline: As Japan Falls Into Recession, Europe Looks to Avoid It
articles.snippet: To revive long-term growth, analysts say deep-seated changes to economies are needed, but such moves are politically difficult.
articles.abstract: To revive long-term growth, analysts say deep-seated changes to economies are needed, but such moves are politically difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Japan looked like the model for economic revival. Growth was back on track. The stock market was surging. Inflation, which had eluded Japan for decades, was even returning.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Jonathan Soble

articles.headline: Justice Department Is Weighing Civil Suit Against Angelo Mozilo
articles.snippet: This summer, federal prosecutors were said to be close to filing a lawsuit. But the acting United States attorney for the Central District of California has had lingering questions about the litigation.
articles.abstract: This summer, federal prosecutors were said to be close to filing a lawsuit. But the acting United States attorney for the Central District of California has had lingering questions about the litigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are wrestling with whether to file a civil fraud lawsuit against Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, which was at the center of the subprime mortgage boom and bust, people briefed on the matter say.

articles.headline: Jamie Horowitz, Newly Hired to Oversee ‘Today,’ Is Fired at NBC
articles.snippet: Mr. Horowitz, a former ESPN executive, is leaving after only 10 weeks in a move attributed to a series of conflicts with staff and management.
articles.abstract: Mr. Horowitz, a former ESPN executive, is leaving after only 10 weeks in a move attributed to a series of conflicts with staff and management.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a new round of turmoil at the long-roiling NBC morning show “Today,” Jamie Horowitz, a former ESPN executive brought in 10 weeks ago to supervise the show, was fired on Monday after what several people at the network said was a series of conflicts with members of the show’s staff as well as the management of NBC News.

articles.headline: Ackman Has Luck of a Loser, to the Tune of $2.2 Billion
articles.snippet: William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals lost their hostile battle to buy Allergan and still came away with a total of $2.6 billion.
articles.abstract: William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals lost their hostile battle to buy Allergan and still came away with a total of $2.6 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heads he wins. Tails he wins.

articles.headline: Mega-Mergers Popular Again on Wall Street
articles.snippet: A pair of deals announced on Monday, worth $100 billion, brought the year’s total for American companies to $1.5 trillion, the highest since 2000.
articles.abstract: A pair of deals announced on Monday, worth $100 billion, brought the year’s total for American companies to $1.5 trillion, the highest since 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks are surging, corporate executives are ambitious and debt is cheap. The result is one of the biggest booms ever in mergers and acquisitions.

articles.headline: Berlin After the Wall: A Microcosm of the World’s Chaotic Change
articles.snippet: Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the city’s identity is still a work in progress.
articles.abstract: Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the city’s identity is still a work in progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Not far from the Brandenburg Gate, Potsdamer Platz was a no man’s land during the Cold War. Then the Berlin Wall fell, and the German authorities made it a petting zoo for celebrity architecture. The corporate headquarters of Germany’s new global swagger.

articles.headline: Israel Shaken by 5 Deaths in Synagogue Assault
articles.snippet: Four men, including three Americans, were killed when two Palestinian assailants stormed a synagogue. A police officer and the attackers also died.
articles.abstract: Four men, including three Americans, were killed when two Palestinian assailants stormed a synagogue. A police officer and the attackers also died.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Orthodox Jewish men were facing east, to honor the Old City site where the ancient temples once stood, when two Palestinians armed with a gun, knives and axes burst into their synagogue Tuesday morning, shouting “God is great!” in Arabic. Within moments, three rabbis and a fourth pious man lay dead, blood pooling on their prayer shawls and holy books.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Isabel Kershner
